article.title: The slight spin of the old stellar halo

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the peak of the distribution in the left panel of Figure 1 indicate about the measured proper motions of QSOs?
choices: They are biased towards positive values.
They have a large scatter.
They are centered around zero, suggesting no systematic bias.
They are not well-constrained.

multiple_choice_question.text: The bottom right panel of Figure 1 shows the dispersion in QSO proper motions as a function of what parameter?
choices: r-band magnitude
g-r color
Time baseline between SDSS and Gaia measurements (ΔT)
Galactic Longitude

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the relationship between proper motion error (σ(μ)) and the time baseline between measurements (ΔT) as shown in the bottom right panel of Figure 1?
choices: σ(μ) is independent of ΔT.
σ(μ) increases linearly with ΔT.
σ(μ) decreases exponentially with ΔT.
σ(μ) decreases as ΔT increases, following an inverse relationship.

multiple_choice_question.text: According to the middle right panel of Figure 1, what can be concluded about the systematic dependence of median QSO proper motions on the time baseline (ΔT)?
choices: There is a strong positive correlation.
There is a strong negative correlation.
There is no significant systematic dependence.
The correlation is dependent on the QSO magnitude.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main purpose of Figure 2?
choices: To show that QSO proper motions are reliable distance indicators.
To demonstrate the dependence of proper motion errors on magnitude and color.
To illustrate the distribution of QSOs in the SDSS-Gaia catalog.
To compare the accuracy of SDSS and Gaia astrometry.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the general trend observed for the dispersion of QSO proper motions (σ(μ)) with r-band magnitude in Figure 2?
choices: σ(μ) decreases with fainter magnitudes.
σ(μ) stays constant across all magnitudes.
σ(μ) increases slightly with fainter magnitudes.
There is no clear trend between σ(μ) and magnitude.

multiple_choice_question.text: What can be concluded about the variation of proper motion errors (σ(μ)) with g-r color based on the right panel of Figure 2?
choices: σ(μ) shows a strong positive correlation with g-r color.
σ(μ) shows a strong negative correlation with g-r color.
There is a weak, insignificant variation of σ(μ) with g-r color.
The correlation between σ(μ) and g-r color is dependent on the magnitude.

multiple_choice_question.text: Why is the negligible variation of proper motion errors with magnitude and color over the studied range important for the study in Figure 2?
choices: It confirms that QSOs are ideal standard candles.
It enables a robust measurement of halo rotation even with significant proper motion errors.
It suggests that the SDSS-Gaia catalog is incomplete.
It implies that halo stars are uniformly distributed in color and magnitude.

multiple_choice_question.text: What type of celestial objects does Figure 3 primarily display?
choices: QSOs
Blue Horizontal Branch stars
RR Lyrae stars
K Giant stars

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the color coding of the points in Figure 3 based on?
choices: Metallicity
Age
Heliocentric distance
Galactic longitude

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the solid black lines in Figure 3 represent?
choices: The Galactic plane.
The celestial equator.
The approximate tracks of the Sagittarius leading and trailing arms.
The boundaries of the SDSS footprint.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the purpose of showing the distribution of RRL stars in this figure?
choices: To highlight the density of RRL stars in the Galactic halo.
To demonstrate the completeness of the SDSS-Gaia catalog.
To illustrate the spatial distribution of the RRL sample used in the study.
To compare the distribution of RRL stars with theoretical models.
